title: Friday, 12th October 2018
bodyHTML:

https://www.ft.com...-b276-b9069bde0956

BE11:12am

Patisserie Holdings, owner of the Patisserie Valerie coffee shop chain, said that finance director Chris Marsh was arrested on Thursday night.

Patisserie Holdings, which this week had disclosed the discovery of significant accounting irregularities, had suspended Mr Marsh from his post on Wednesday.

The Aim-listed company, which operates a chain of more than 200 cafés across the UK, said Mr Marsh had been released on bail.

“Further updates will be released in due course,” Patisserie Holdings said on Friday in a statement to the market. Mr Marsh could not immediately be reached for comment.

What's happened here tho? Dunno. Can't speculate. But if you happen to pass a Pat Val today, do head in for a mille feuille and make sure you tip very, very well.

First things first, if the story's accurate (and we've no reason to doubt it), there would be no reason for Equiniti to make a statement. It's written carefully from the perspective of pre-approach.

BE11:20am

GTCR might be bounced into making a statement based on specific speculation, or it might avoid doing so by going pens down.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

The background here is a rumour around Equiniti that started towards the back end of last month ......

That follows Panmure effectively issuing a short report on Equiniti in July: https://www.ft.com...-a29d-73e3d454535d

ValueFirst Re: SMT - we should thank Baillie Gifford for producing a liquid, easy-to-borrow vehicle with which to short the US / China tech bubble. Even better when they use leverage and trade at a premium to NAV.
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Let me get a recent thing from Citi to outline the risks once again.

Electric Dragon Interesting fact about Lyons: they were one of the pioneers of business computing - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LEO_(computer)
BE11:24am

The three significant issues relating to the financial statements reviewed by the both
the committee and PWC were:
 Revenue recognition on complex contracts.
 Other items included in revenue including accruals for revenue (£33m in 20017 v £28m in 2016) in advance of invoicing customers involving management judgement and estimates.
 Classification of exceptional items – movement away from reporting exceptional items separately in the financial statements and towards presenting “underlying” earnings with a bridge from statutory earnings. Initially management had proposed defining £10.5m transaction, integration and restructuring costs (mainly relating to WFSS) as exceptional but following discussions with the Audit Committee and PWC, the disclosure was changed to “non-operating charges”.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian "Everyone's rotated what they were wanting to rotate and now we're rotating back into what we just rotated out of" - Never a truer word spoken!
BE11:24am

During 2017, Equiniti received a letter from the FRC with some questions and observations about its 2016 report. These unnamed observations were mainly about disclosures and have been incorporated into the 2016 annual report. These were around:
 Revenue accounting policies
 Sensitivity of carrying amounts to their methods, assumptions and underlying estimates
 Exceptional items
 Contingent consideration
The FRC’s enquiry is now formally closed and management says the two main changes in disclosure related to non-operating charges and the use of the invoice factoring facility.

Excel Developer Nice to see GBPUSD holding above 1.32 Dollar rally has paused, what happens next, whither the dollar?
11:24 am
BE11:25am

And the one-offs ........

BE11:25am

Equiniti continued its trend of stripping out one-off costs from underlying profits. In 2017, these amounted to 14% of EBITA (adj), mainly relating to the WFSS acquisition.

BE11:25am

And the capitalisation policy ....

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Equiniti has continued its trend of capitalizing more software costs than it amortizes. This gap equated to 12% of PBT (adj) in 2017 up from 9% in 2016. Equiniti has increased spend on regulatory compliance (e.g. MIFID II), software development mainly in Intelligent Solutions and the build out of the US business. The useful life for software assets is generally set at 5 years unless there is a supportable reason for a higher or lower period. This implies a gradual step up in amortisation in the next few years, which could weigh on margins.

BE11:26am

And the provisions .....

BE11:26am

In 2017, Equiniti released £1.6m provisions including £1.5m for contingent
consideration. This was included in underlying profits and equated to 40bp of margin or c40% of the YOY EBITA growth.
Management however flags a number of offsetting non-recurring costs included in underlying profits including related to acquiring Boudicca and restructuring costs in Pensions.

tonyb Betaville: "These sources claimed GTCR could be willing to pay between 315p and 325p a share for Equiniti.." So 50% premium to current share price! is this believable?
Electric Dragon Or if you live in Manchester/Leeds/Birmingham, go to a Philpotts sandwich shop - a favourite of mine when I worked in Manc city centre about ten ago that I learnt this week had been acquired by Pat Val in 2014.
DJ Equiniti sounds like short of the year
11:27 am
BE11:27am

There are lots of reasons to be cautious about Equiniti and there are circumstantial reasons to believe it's potentially for sale. Whether GTCR's a serious buyer is another question entirely.

BE11:27am

But if there's anything needing said, I'm sure we can trust the Panel to make someone say it.

Electric Dragon ten *years* ago (how time flies)

It uses a repeat of 2008 as a proxy for no-deal.

BE11:30am

We find that, even under a severe market correction, Barratt is able to maintain an average dividend cash cover of 2.8x between FY19-21e periods.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Here's an amazing figure ... Barratt has over the past five years done £2bn of net operating cashflow.

BE11:31am

Not by building houses! To be clear! At least, not that many. Volume's gone from 14,191 units in 2014 to 16,680 in 2018

BE11:32am

Anyway, the model here suggests total housing completions down 41% peak to trough and UK house prices down 21% peak to trough, same as 2008.

And versus the takeover defence stuff you have a very high possibility of another downgrade, as per Berenberg yesteday:

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Despite the FY18 outlook downgrade at Q2 results we expect the company to report Q3 sales growth of 2% FX-neutral with an EBITDA of 30.2% (-760bp yoy), both below the already revised full-year guidance. This is likely to put the sustainability of its outlook in question once again. Although we continue to believe that Pandora is positioned in an attractive jewellery space and thanks to its vertically integrated business model has a competitive advantage versus its peers, its currently unclear long-term strategic plan and limited actions to address the deteriorating like-for-likes performance mean we believe it is too early to turn constructive on the name

jaws anything in KNOS please ? KAINOS GROUP
BE11:42am

As the de-stocking among wholesale customers accelerates and growth continues to be solely driven by retail expansion, we believe a weak Q3 could once again put the sustainability of the already lowered outlook in question. Based on our current FY18 estimates Pandora will need to see 5% FX-neutral sales growth in Q4 to reach the bottom of its full-year outlook, and an EBITDA of ~33.4% (-670bp yoy). However, we note that this will come off a tougher comparable basis where the company, by its own admission, left no orders unfulfilled in Q4 2017 to achieve its FY17 outlook.

BE11:43am

Dangerous one to chase even if they can shake out actual interest. Add to the list that already includes Equiniti, RPC, Intu .....

11:48 am
Victrex PLC (VCT:LSE): Last: 2,560, down 184 (-6.71%), High: 2,710, Low: 2,554, Volume: 247.55k
Blank canvas John Authers must be commended for not going to the PR trough
BE11:49am

Cyclical downturn, end markets going worse, valuation punchy, competition and/or margin attrition possible as it moves down the value-to-volume scale, etc.

jaws J P Morgan beat news
BE11:50am

Check out the Specialty Polymer Pyramid.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

TonaldDrump re: the rotation malarky https://twitter.com/jmackin2/status/1050699469434617856
BE11:50am

That's this year's Christmas card sorted. Anyhoo, here's MOST:

BE11:51am

Are PEEK volumes at risk? Victrex has enjoyed very strong volume growth from the trough levels in H1'16, correlating closely with the global cyclical recovery. This growth has been most notable in value added resellers (most exposed to Asia, low visibility), electronics and auto. Given signs of slowing growth in key markets like automotive, electronics and industrial (75% of vol's), we expect the rate of growth pa seen in the last 2 years of 14% and 13% respectively (excl. consumer electronics) to slow significantly to 3.6% in FY'19. Accounting for these changes we are 2.5% below consensus EPS in FY'19 and 6.5% below in FY'20.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Is a special dividend every year the base case? The recent UK patent box ruling has greatly reduced Victrex's tax rate to 10%, improving free cash generation; as such the market and cons. now expect it to pay a special divi every year, applying the co's existing cash return policy (c. 50% of net free cash provided that equates to min 50p special divi), greatly increasing the implied dividend yield. However, we believe this might not be the base case, accounting for (1) continued investment in the front end of the business; (2) potential for rising capex FY'20-'23 to account for a future PEEK capacity expansion; and (3) desire to accelerate inorganic investment in downstream activities. We forecast an average divi yield of 3.2% pa between FY'18-22 versus a consensus average of ~4% pa.

BE11:51am

All-time high valuation looks exposed given growth risks. Victrex trades at alltime high relative valuation versus EU chemicals, on 22x FY'19e PE, and 16x FY'19e EV/EBITDA. The valuation is the highest it has been in the last 20 years, with the market seemingly willing to believe in the sustainability of the growth profile as well as assume bull case dividend returns. Victrex is a quality business, but we believe that the growth profile is more cyclical, and that the company faces longer term challenges to execute on its mega programs in an increasingly competitive specialty polymer market as compounding becomes mainstream. With the risk reward heavily skewed to the downside we move Underweight.

GBKrona Always enjoyed Auther's insights - and he left FT very much through the front door.

We see this as a short-term headache and a long-term opportunity for Genus. As a consequence, we see the share price setback as providing an opportunity for an interesting entry point. Genus is trading on a PE of 28.6x to June 2019E and 25.9x excluding the investment in gene editing
